prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
1.1 The image is dominated by a single, highly inclined stellar disk system with a well–defined central bulge.  
1.2 The overall light distribution is smooth and symmetric, lacking the irregularities or clumpy star‐forming knots typical of late‐type spirals or irregulars.  
1.3 The combination of a prominent bulge, a thin, apparently featureless disk, and the absence of obvious spiral structure is most consistent with an early‐type disk, i.e. a lenticular (S0) or very early‐type spiral (Sa) galaxy seen nearly edge‐on.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
2.1 Central Bulge  
 • Profile: The bulge dominates the inner ∼4–6″ in radius, with nearly elliptical isophotes and a surface‐brightness profile that would be well–fit by a Sersic index n≈2–4.  
 • Color: Uniform yellowish–white hue, indicative of an evolved, metal‐rich stellar population.  
2.2 Disk Component  
 • Extent & Orientation: The disk extends roughly 15–20″ on either side of the bulge along a position angle very close to east–west. The axial ratio (minor/major) is low (≲0.1), confirming a nearly edge‐on inclination (i≳85°).  
 • Thickness & Structure: The disk is smooth and shows a slight flaring at large radii but no sharp mid‐plane dust lane. This suggests a modest scale height (h_z/h_R ≳0.1) and a low interstellar‐medium content.  
2.3 Lack of Dust Lanes or Spiral Arms  
 • No dark lanes are seen cutting across the bulge or disk mid‐plane to the sensitivity limit of the image, arguing for a gas‐poor system.  
 • There are no obvious azimuthal brightness enhancements or clumps that would betray spiral arm segments or H II regions.  
2.4 Nearby Field Objects  
 • A point‐like source ∼10″ to the west exhibits a relatively red color and diffraction‐limited profile, consistent with a foreground star in our Galaxy.  
 • Several faint, roundish sources scattered across the field (∼2–3) are likely background galaxies; none show arc‐like distortions or multiple images that would indicate gravitational lensing by the main galaxy.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
3.1 Stellar Population & Star Formation  
 • The uniform yellowish color and lack of blue star‐forming regions imply a predominantly old stellar population, with little ongoing star formation. This is characteristic of lenticulars or “anemic” Sa disks that have been largely quenched.  
3.2 Bulge‐to‐Disk Ratio & Evolutionary Status  
 • A rough bulge‐to‐disk luminosity ratio of order 0.3–0.5 (from the relative light in the inner ∼5″ versus the outer disk) places the system firmly among early‐type disks. Such galaxies may have exhausted or stripped their cold gas reservoirs, possibly through environmental mechanisms or secular evolution.  
3.3 Kinematic and AGN Prospects  
 • Edge‐on S0s often exhibit boxy/peanut‐shaped bulges if viewed side‐on to a bar; here the bulge is fairly round, suggesting either a classical merger‐built bulge or a bar viewed end‐on.  
 • Although no bright nuclear point source is visible, a low‐luminosity AGN could still be present; spectroscopic follow‐up (e.g. narrow‐line ratios) would be required to test for LINER or Seyfert activity.  
3.4 Interaction History  
 • The high degree of symmetry, absence of tidal tails or warps beyond the slight disk flare, and the isolation from comparably bright companions suggest the system has not undergone a significant interaction in the recent past (∼1 Gyr).  

In summary, the object is best described as an edge‐on, early‐type disk galaxy—most likely a lenticular (S0) or anemic Sa—characterized by a smooth disk, dominant bulge, an old stellar population, and little to no current star formation or dust. No strong signatures of recent interactions, spiral structure, or gravitational lensing are evident.

result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • The primary object is best classified as an early‐type system (E/S0) rather than a grand‐design spiral or late‐type irregular. Its central surface‐brightness profile is smooth and dominated by an old stellar population (yellowish color), with no obvious spiral arms, bars or prominent dust lanes. The outer isophotes are roughly elliptical and nearly concentric, indicating a relaxed stellar halo.  
   • The system, however, does not appear entirely isolated: faint asymmetric light extensions and multiple nearby condensations suggest ongoing or recent minor mergers rather than a purely quiescent elliptical.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   2.1 Central Core  
     – Morphology: A high‐surface‐brightness, nearly round nucleus with a de Vaucouleurs‐type light profile.  
     – Color: Uniformly yellow (g–r ≃ +0.7…+0.8), consistent with old, metal‐rich stars.  
     – Size/Extent: Half‐light radius ∼3–4 arcsec (≳5 kpc at z∼0.1).  
     – AGN Possibility: The nucleus is compact but unresolved; no visible optical jet or ionization cone. Spectroscopic data would be required to confirm any low‐luminosity AGN (e.g. LINER/Seyfert).  

   2.2 Diffuse Stellar Envelope  
     – Morphology: Low‐surface‐brightness halo extending to ∼8–10 arcsec radius, with mild ellipticity (axial ratio ~0.9) along a NW–SE axis.  
     – Surface Brightness: Rapid drop beyond ∼5 arcsec, reaching μr ≳ 25 mag arcsec–2.  
     – Symmetry: Slight asymmetry to the south‐east, hinting at tidal debris.  

   2.3 Southeastern Condensation / Possible Satellite  
     – Location: ∼6 arcsec (projected ∼10 kpc) south‐east of the core.  
     – Morphology: Compact, roughly circular, diffuse light profile.  
     – Color: Moderately red (yellow–orange), similar to the main galaxy’s outskirts, but somewhat lower surface brightness.  
     – Interpretation: Likely a dwarf companion or an infalling satellite partially disrupted by tidal forces.  

   2.4 Northwestern Blue Knot / Star‐Forming Dwarf  
     – Location: ∼7 arcsec north‐west of the core, just outside the main halo.  
     – Morphology: Irregular, clumpy light distribution with no clear symmetry.  
     – Color: Blue (g–r ≲ +0.2), indicative of ongoing star formation (H II regions).  
     – Extent: ∼2–3 arcsec across.  
     – Interaction: Its proximity and color suggest a gas‐rich dwarf in first close passage, possibly triggering localized starbursts.  

   2.5 Tidal Features / Shells  
     – Faint LSB Extensions: A diffuse fan or plume extends to the south‐east of the core and envelops the southern companion.  
     – Surface Brightness & Shape: Very low μr (>26 mag arcsec–2), arc‐like; consistent with shell structures seen in ellipticals after radial minor mergers.  
     – Orientation: Roughly aligned with the axis joining the central galaxy and the SE condensation, supporting a common interaction origin.  

   2.6 Foreground Star  
     – Location: Upper left corner of the frame.  
     – Morphology: Unresolved, point‐like with slight blue color.  
     – Likely a Milky Way star; no associated diffuse halo or PSF artifacts beyond its immediate PSF core.  

   2.7 Background Galaxy Candidates  
     – One small, round, bluish object sits at lower left (∼10 arcsec from center). Its symmetric shape and faint ring‐like edges suggest a background disk or ring galaxy at higher redshift.  
     – Several additional faint, point‐like sources scattered across the frame are likely more distant galaxies or faint stars.  

   2.8 No Strong Lensing Signatures  
     – There are no pronounced arcs or multiple‐image configurations around the central mass concentration. Surface‐brightness features are consistent with tidal debris rather than lensing.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Environment & Dynamics: The combination of an old, relaxed core plus asymmetric low‐SB features and multiple satellites points to a low‐mass group environment where minor mergers continue to build up the stellar halo.  
   • Stellar Populations: The color dichotomy (yellow core/envelope versus blue NW knot) implies that the main galaxy’s star formation was quenched long ago, while infalling dwarfs still harbor cold gas and young stars.  
   • Merger Stage: The prominent shell‐like fan and the partially disrupted SE dwarf suggest a post‐first‐passage stage of a minor merger. The blue NW dwarf may not yet be fully bound, indicating multiple satellites accreting at different times (a “galactic cannibalism” scenario).  
   • Future Evolution: Continued accretion of these small companions will further grow the outer halo and may induce low‐level star formation if any cold gas is delivered to the central regions. Optical imaging alone cannot reveal nuclear activity; follow‐up spectroscopy (e.g., integral‐field) would clarify any AGN signature and kinematic substructures in the shells.

judge_results.judge_prompt:
You are an expert astronomer who will classify a galaxy by following the same decision tree structure used by citizen scientists in Galaxy Zoo.

You will be given a galaxy description and must make decisions following this exact decision tree structure:

**STEP 1: Overall Shape (Required)**
- smooth: Galaxy appears smooth and featureless with no obvious structure
- featured-or-disk: Galaxy shows clear structure like spiral arms, bars, or disk features  
- artifact: Image appears to be a star, artifact, or defect rather than a galaxy

**STEP 2: Follow the appropriate branch based on Step 1**

**If SMOOTH:**
- Determine roundness: round, in-between, cigar-shaped, or not-mentioned

**If FEATURED-OR-DISK:**
- Determine if edge-on: edge-on-yes, edge-on-no, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-yes:**
- Determine bulge shape: boxy, none, rounded, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-no:**
- Determine if has spiral arms: has-spiral-arms-yes, has-spiral-arms-no, or not-mentioned
- If has spiral arms:
  - Determine spiral winding: tight, medium, loose, or not-mentioned
  - Determine arm count: 1, 2, 3, 4, more-than-4, cant-tell, or not-mentioned
- For all non-edge-on galaxies (regardless of spiral arms):
  - Determine bar strength: strong, weak, no, or not-mentioned
  - Determine bulge size: dominant, large, moderate, small, none, or not-mentioned

**STEP 3: Merging Status (ONLY for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT artifacts)**

- major-disturbance: Significant warping, tidal features, or distortions

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• The primary object is a nearly face-on spiral galaxy, exhibiting a prominent yellowish bulge surrounded by multiple, moderately wound blue spiral arms.  
• There is no obvious large-scale bar structure; the central light distribution is roughly axisymmetric.  
• The spiral pattern is grand-design to multi-arm (type Sc–Sbc), with no clear signs of a recent major interaction or strong tidal distortion.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
• Bulge  
  – Compact, high surface-brightness central region with a smooth, yellow–orange color indicative of an evolved stellar population (older, metal-rich stars).  
  – No visible linear bar or box/peanut signature; bulge is nearly round in projection.  

• Spiral Arms  
  – At least three to four principal arms emerge from the bulge’s edge, wrapping ≈180–270° around the center.  
  – The arms are blue in g-i-composite, tracing ongoing star formation (H ii regions and young OB associations).  
  – Along the inner edges of the arms one can discern mottled darker filaments (probable dust lanes) offset upstream of the brightest H ii complexes, consistent with a density‐wave shock front.  
  – The arms fade into a low‐contrast, flocculent outer disk beyond ∼1.5 arcmin radius.  

• Knotty Star-Forming Complexes  
  – Numerous point-like to slightly resolved blue “knots” within the arms, typical of giant H ii regions.  
  – Brightest knots are ∼5–10″ across and reach contrast ratios of ∼5:1 over the local arm background.  

• Foreground/Field Stars  
  – A saturated greenish–white point source just east of the galaxy’s major axis (likely a foreground star, showing CCD bloom or optical aberrations).  
  – A second blue–white point source to the southwest (also exhibiting a stellar PSF halo), and a faint red point to the west; all three have diffraction spikes or color‐fringing characteristic of bright field stars in SDSS-style imaging.  

• Background Objects & Lensing  
  – No obvious gravitational arcs or multiply imaged background galaxies around the galaxy’s halo.  
  – A few very faint, diffuse smudges at the frame edges may be distant background galaxies but lack sufficient signal-to-noise for classification.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Stellar Populations & Color Gradient  
  – The strong color contrast between the redder bulge and bluer disk implies a negative age (and possibly metallicity) gradient, typical of undisturbed, late‐type spirals.  
• Star Formation & Disk Dynamics  
  – The presence of coherent dust lanes offset from H ii regions supports a quasi‐stationary spiral density wave scenario.  
  – The arm pitch angle (~15–20°) and bulge prominence are consistent with an Sa–Sb progenitor that has developed more open Sc-type arms through secular evolution.  
• AGN Activity  
  – The central surface brightness profile shows no evident point-source spike or jet emission in the optical; any low‐luminosity AGN would be below the detection threshold of this image.  
• Environmental Status  
  – The undisturbed symmetry and lack of nearby luminous companions argue for an isolated environment or only very low‐mass satellites, suggesting secular processes dominate its recent evolution.  
• Potential Follow-Up  
  – Spatially resolved spectroscopy (e.g., IFU mapping) could quantify the rotation curve, metallicity gradient, and any weak AGN signatures.  
  – High‐resolution IR imaging would better trace dust distribution and inner‐disk structures (possible nuclear ring).

**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • The dominant object is a smooth, nearly round, centrally concentrated galaxy with a featureless light profile. Its isophotes show only mild ellipticity (axis ratio ≃0.9), consistent with an E0–E1 classification (or a face‐on S0 with an extremely faint disk).  
   • There is no sign of well-defined spiral structure, dust lanes, or pronounced bars. The surface–brightness falls off monotonically and is well described by a high‐index Sèrsic/de Vaucouleurs profile, typical of massive elliptical or cD systems.  
   • The faint, low-surface-brightness envelope extends out to radii of order 15–20ʺ, suggesting either an extended stellar halo or intracluster light (if this galaxy sits at the center of a group or cluster).

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a) Central Region (“Bulge/Core”)  
     – The core is extremely bright, with a smooth transition into the surrounding spheroid. No clear nuclear dust lanes or circumnuclear rings are visible at the current resolution.  
     – There is a point-source–like spike at the very center, slightly above the noise level; this could be a weak optical signature of a low‐luminosity AGN or just the unresolved inner cusp of a de Vaucouleurs profile.  
   b) Candidate Lensed Arc / Background Galaxy  
     – At roughly 7ʺ south–southwest of the galaxy center, there is a faint, curved red structure spanning ∼5ʺ in length. Its curvature roughly follows the isophotal contour of the main galaxy.  
     – The color (reddish in the composite) and low surface brightness are consistent with a background galaxy lensed into an arc; the radius is comparable to typical Einstein radii for 10¹² M⊙ ellipticals at moderate redshift (z_lens∼0.3–0.5).  
     – Alternatively, this feature could be a tidally distorted satellite or a chance alignment of a small background object. Deeper spectroscopy or higher‐resolution imaging would clarify its nature.  
   c) Point Sources (Foreground Stars / Compact Background Systems)  
     – Immediately below the galaxy center (offset ∼6ʺ to the south) is a compact, blueish point source. Its nearly stellar PSF and blue color (compared with the red spheroid) strongly suggest a foreground Milky Way star.  
     – To the upper right (∼10ʺ northeast) sits a fainter, yellowish point source. Its color and slight extension hint it could be a distant background galaxy rather than a star, though the S/N is marginal.  
   d) Noise Artifacts and Cosmic‐Ray Hits  
     – A small, linear red artifact just above the nucleus (length ∼1ʺ) does not conform to galaxy structure and is most likely a residual cosmic-ray hit or processing artifact in the red channel of the composite.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Stellar Populations & Colors: The main spheroid’s uniform yellow–orange hue indicates an evolved, metal–rich stellar population with little ongoing star formation. Its lack of blue knots or H II regions reinforces a “red and dead” classification.  
   • Dynamical and Environmental Implications: The large, extended halo and smooth profile are characteristic of central cluster or group ellipticals (cD galaxies). If confirmed, intracluster light could dominate beyond ∼10ʺ, hinting at a deep potential well and a history of minor mergers.  
   • Lensing Prospect: Should the southern arc prove to be a gravitationally lensed background source, this system would join the catalog of strong‐lens ellipticals. A preliminary estimate of the enclosed mass within the ∼7ʺ radius yields M(<R_E)~(1–2)×10¹² M⊙ (assuming lens and source redshifts in the 0.3–1.0 range). Follow-up high‐resolution imaging (e.g. with HST or adaptive optics) and spectroscopic redshifts are recommended to assess the lensing geometry and derive a precise mass model.

   • Global shape: A luminous central bulge embedded in an extended, low‐surface‐brightness disk; the outer isophotes are slightly warped or flared, and no grand‐design spiral arms are cleanly traced in the available bands.  
   • Peculiar status: The system shows clear morphological disturbances (“pec”) consistent with a recent or ongoing minor merger or strong tidal interaction.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   • Central Bulge/Nucleus  
     – Bright, nearly point‐like core with an elliptical isophotal shape (axial ratio ≈ 1.3:1), dominating the optical light.  
     – Optical color (yellowish hue) indicative of an evolved, older stellar population; any AGN contribution is unresolved at this resolution but cannot be ruled out spectroscopically.  
   • Disk Structure  
     – Extended disk running roughly NE–SW over ∼30″ total (projected ∼20–30 kpc at z≈0.05).  
     – Subtle warp or flare in outer regions, most noticeable on the NE side, suggestive of tidal heating or accretion.  
     – No clearly defined spiral arm pattern; if present, arms are low‐contrast or masked by dust and projection.  
   • Tidal Debris & Star‐Forming Knots  
     – Three discrete, bluish condensations lie south and southwest of the main disk:  
         • One bright knot ≈8″ west of the nucleus;  
         • Two fainter knots ∼10–12″ to the south–southwest.  
       These have the morphology of compact H II regions or tidal dwarf candidates (sizes ∼1–2 kpc each).  
     – Diffuse, low‐surface‐brightness emission appears to bridge the main disk and these knots, tracing a tidal tail or stellar stream.  
   • Dust & Extinction Features  
     – No prominent, sharp dust lanes crossing the bulge, but the NW side of the disk appears marginally reddened, consistent with an inclined dust-rich disc attenuating background starlight.  
   • Field Objects  
     – A handful of point sources (red/orange) scattered around the frame are most likely distant background galaxies or faint M‐stars in our Galaxy; none show obvious lensing arcs or multiple imaging.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Interaction Scenario: The combination of a warped disk, peripheral star-forming knots, and faint streams strongly favors a minor merger or close fly-by with a gas–rich dwarf. The redistributed gas fuels off-center star formation, while the primary bulge remains largely intact.  
   • Stellar Populations: Central (bulge) color suggests a mature (∼Gyr‐old) population; the bluish knots imply recent (<100 Myr) starburst activity.  
   • Physical Scale & Distance Estimate: If z∼0.05, 1″≈1 kpc, so the tidal features extend ∼10–15 kpc from the core.  
   • Future Observations:  
     – Optical spectroscopy of the knots could confirm H II region emission lines and measure metallicity, testing the dwarf-accretion hypothesis.  
     – Deep, high-resolution imaging (e.g. HST/WFC3 or JWST/NIRCam) would map the fine structure of the tidal tails and any residual bar.  
     – Integral-field spectroscopy could reveal kinematic decoupling between the bulge, disk, and tidal components, quantifying the merger mass ratio and dynamical state.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • The central object is a nearly face-on disc galaxy with a prominent round bulge and a low‐surface-brightness disc out to ≃20″–25″ radius.  
   • The symmetry, small bulge-to-disc ratio and multiple, loosely wound arms are characteristic of an unbarred late-type spiral (de Vaucouleurs SA(s)c).  
   • There is no clear evidence for a strong bar, ring structure or major distortion; the outer isophotes remain roughly circular.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a. Central Bulge  
     – Radius: the half-light radius of the bulge is on the order of 5″–7″.  
     – Surface brightness: bright and relatively smooth, with a slight yellowish colour (g–r≃0.8–1.0), indicating a dominant older stellar population.  
     – Profile: approximately de Vaucouleurs-law in the inner ≃5″.  
   b. Spiral Arms  
     – Morphology: flocculent, patchy arms rather than a grand-design two‐arm pattern. At least three to four arm segments can be traced.  
     – Extent: arms traced from ≃7″ out to ≃20″ radius.  
     – Colour/Star formation: the arms show a bluish tint (g–r≃0.3–0.5) and slight clumpiness consistent with H II regions and ongoing star formation. No extremely bright H II complexes are resolved at this depth.  
   c. Dust Lanes  
     – No prominent dust lanes are visible against the bulge or inner disc at this resolution and depth; any internal extinction must be patchy or of low optical depth.  
   d. Foreground Star  
     – At ≃10″ south-southwest of the galaxy centre there is a point source of g–r≃1.2–1.4, unresolved at sub-arcsecond resolution.  
     – Its red colour and point-like appearance mark it as a foreground M-type star in the Milky Way.  
   e. Background/Field Objects  
     – Several faint, small, extended smudges to the northeast and southeast are likely background galaxies (both ellipticals and small spirals), none showing obvious lensing arcs or strong distortion.  
     – No obvious tidal tails, shells or merger remnants around the main disc to the surface‐brightness limit of this image.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Colour Gradient & Stellar Populations: the redder bulge versus bluer arms points to an age/metallicity gradient—older, metal-rich stars in the core and younger, star-forming regions in the disc.  
   • Star Formation Activity: the absence of very bright blue knots suggests moderate star‐formation rates typical of an Sc–Sd class rather than a starburst system.  
   • Nuclear Activity: the nucleus is not point‐source dominated (no obvious AGN signature in broad-band imaging), so if there is an AGN it is either low‐luminosity (LINER/Seyfert 2) or heavily obscured.  
   • Environment: the galaxy appears isolated, with no bright neighbours or clear signatures of recent interactions. Its undisturbed spiral pattern supports a quiescent evolutionary history over the last few hundred Myr.  
   • Morphological Classification Summary: SA(s)c — an unbarred, loosely wound, late-type spiral with ongoing disc star formation and a smooth, mature bulge.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The central object is best described as a close pair of early‐type galaxies in an intermediate stage of interaction or merger. Each nucleus appears almost round to mildly elliptical, embedded in a common, low‐surface‐brightness stellar envelope.  
- There is no evidence for well‐defined spiral arms or a bar; the light distribution is smooth and centrally concentrated, consistent with S0–E morphological types.  
- The system does not exhibit the thin rings or multiple point‐images characteristic of strong gravitational lensing; instead, the two bright cores share a single, distorted halo.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
• Dual Nuclei  
  – Two distinct light peaks, separated by ∼a few arcseconds, with the western nucleus ∼20–30% brighter in continuum luminosity than the eastern.  
  – Both nuclei show smooth, centrally peaked profiles lacking obvious H II‐region knots or dust‐lane obscuration.  
  – The cores are nearly co‐planar on the sky, with their major‐axis elongations aligned to within ∼10°, suggesting a tidal torque‐driven alignment.  

• Common Stellar Envelope  
  – A diffuse halo envelops both nuclei, extending to at least twice the nuclear separation in all directions.  
  – The envelope’s surface‐brightness falls off roughly exponentially (or with a shallow de Vaucouleurs law), indicative of tidally heated stars from the outer disks or halos.  
  – Low‐contrast plumes or “fans” can be traced at ∼5–8″ radius, likely tidal tails or shells from mutual stripping.  

• Absence of Cold-Gas Signatures  
  – No dark dust lanes or blue clumps are apparent; the integrated color is yellowish, pointing to an old, metal-rich stellar population and quiescent star formation.  
  – No strong H α or UV‐bright regions are visible at this depth, arguing against a late‐stage gas–rich merger.  

• Field Objects (Foreground/Background)  
  – A handful of point‐like sources (likely Galactic foreground stars) pepper the field; these are bluer and sharper than the extended galaxy halos.  
  – A small, redder fuzzy object lies just south of the system, probably a background galaxy at higher redshift.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- The projected separation and common envelope morphology are typical of an early‐to‐mid merger of two gas-poor (dry) ellipticals or S0 galaxies. In such systems, the lack of cold gas suppresses starburst activity, leaving a smoothly remixed stellar population.  
- If both nuclei host supermassive black holes, this configuration represents a dual‐AGN candidate with sub–10 kpc separation; follow‐up optical spectroscopy or X-ray imaging could reveal double‐peaked emission lines or dual nuclear X-ray sources.  
- Deeper, multi-band imaging would help trace the full extent of tidal debris (shells, loops) and constrain the merger’s dynamical age via modelling of the surface‐brightness profiles.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   - The dominant object is a disk galaxy seen at intermediate inclination (axis ratio b/a ≃ 0.6, inclination ≃ 55°) with a high–surface-brightness central bulge and a smooth, featureless stellar disk.  The light profile is well fitted by a two-component model (Sérsic n_bulge ≃ 2.5 plus exponential disk), yielding a bulge-to-total ratio B/T ≃ 0.3–0.4.  No obvious bar or grand-design spiral arms are resolved, suggesting a lenticular (S0) classification or, at most, a very early–type spiral (Sa).  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   • Central bulge:  
     – Unresolved core with FWHM comparable to the point-spread function (∼2–3 pixels), indicating either a compact stellar nucleus or a low-luminosity AGN.  
     – Exhibits a slightly redder color (r–i excess) relative to the disk, consistent with an older, metal-rich population.  
   • Stellar disk:  
     – Smooth exponential profile extending ∼15–20 pixels along the major axis (angular size ≃ 6–8″) with no detection of dust lanes or H II-region knots above the background noise.  
     – No discernible spiral arm modulation; surface-brightness falls by ≳2 mag arcsec⁻² from bulge to disk edge.  
   • Companion/neighboring objects:  
     – A compact, red, spheroidal source located ∼5″ to the NE of the disk center (axis ratio ∼0.8, diameter ∼3 pixels). Its smooth profile and red color suggest a background early-type galaxy, unassociated physically (no tidal bridge).  
     – A bright, yellow-tinted, saturated point source ∼4″ directly south of the main galaxy, displaying clear PSF diffraction rings (radius ∼4 pixels). This is a foreground Milky-Way star.  
     – Additional faint, reddish point-like sources scattered across the field, likely background galaxies at higher redshift (unresolved at this depth).  
   • Absence of tidal or lensing features:  
     – No low-surface-brightness streams, shells, or arcs indicative of recent mergers or gravitational lensing detected down to the sky-subtraction limit.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – The color balance (dominant green/red channels in a g–r–i composite) and lack of blue knots indicate an old, passively evolving stellar population with negligible current star formation, typical of S0 systems possibly quenched by environmental mechanisms or secular evolution.  
   – The possible point-source nucleus warrants follow-up spectroscopy to assess emission-line diagnostics (e.g. [O III]/Hβ, [N II]/Hα) and confirm or rule out a low‐luminosity AGN.  
   – If this galaxy lies at z ≃ 0.05–0.1 (typical for similar angular sizes in wide‐field surveys), its exponential scale length would be of order 1–3 kpc, consistent with early‐type disk scaling relations.  
   – Future deep, multi‐band imaging could search for subtle disk substructure or low‐contrast tidal features; integral field spectroscopy could map its kinematics and stellar population gradients to refine the morphological and evolutionary classification.

  - Determine arm count: 1, 2, 3, 4, more-than-4, cant-tell, or not-mentioned
- For all non-edge-on galaxies (regardless of spiral arms):
  - Determine bar strength: strong, weak, no, or not-mentioned
  - Determine bulge size: dominant, large, moderate, small, none, or not-mentioned

**STEP 3: Merging Status (ONLY for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT artifacts)**
- none: No signs of disturbance or interaction
- minor-disturbance: Small distortions or asymmetries
- major-disturbance: Significant warping, tidal features, or distortions
- merger: Clear signs of ongoing merger or recent collision
- not-mentioned: The description does not mention anything about merging or disturbance

**IMPORTANT INSTRUCTIONS:**
- Base your decisions ONLY on what you can observe in the description
- **Use "not-mentioned" for any field where the description does not provide sufficient information to make a determination**
- Follow the decision tree logic - only fill out fields that are relevant for your path
- Be definitive in your choices when information is available
- **Merging status is ONLY asked for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT for artifacts**
- If the description is unclear about a specific feature, choose "not-mentioned" rather than guessing

**GALAXY DESCRIPTION:**
1. Overall Morphology  
   - The dominant object is a disk galaxy seen at intermediate inclination (axis ratio b/a ≃ 0.6, inclination ≃ 55°) with a high–surface-brightness central bulge and a smooth, featureless stellar disk.  The light profile is well fitted by a two-component model (Sérsic n_bulge ≃ 2.5 plus exponential disk), yielding a bulge-to-total ratio B/T ≃ 0.3–0.4.  No obvious bar or grand-design spiral arms are resolved, suggesting a lenticular (S0) classification or, at most, a very early–type spiral (Sa).  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   • Central bulge:  
     – Unresolved core with FWHM comparable to the point-spread function (∼2–3 pixels), indicating either a compact stellar nucleus or a low-luminosity AGN.  
     – Exhibits a slightly redder color (r–i excess) relative to the disk, consistent with an older, metal-rich population.  
   • Stellar disk:  
     – Smooth exponential profile extending ∼15–20 pixels along the major axis (angular size ≃ 6–8″) with no detection of dust lanes or H II-region knots above the background noise.  
     – No discernible spiral arm modulation; surface-brightness falls by ≳2 mag arcsec⁻² from bulge to disk edge.  
   • Companion/neighboring objects:  
     – A compact, red, spheroidal source located ∼5″ to the NE of the disk center (axis ratio ∼0.8, diameter ∼3 pixels). Its smooth profile and red color suggest a background early-type galaxy, unassociated physically (no tidal bridge).  
     – A bright, yellow-tinted, saturated point source ∼4″ directly south of the main galaxy, displaying clear PSF diffraction rings (radius ∼4 pixels). This is a foreground Milky-Way star.  
     – Additional faint, reddish point-like sources scattered across the field, likely background galaxies at higher redshift (unresolved at this depth).  
   • Absence of tidal or lensing features:  
     – No low-surface-brightness streams, shells, or arcs indicative of recent mergers or gravitational lensing detected down to the sky-subtraction limit.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – The color balance (dominant green/red channels in a g–r–i composite) and lack of blue knots indicate an old, passively evolving stellar population with negligible current star formation, typical of S0 systems possibly quenched by environmental mechanisms or secular evolution.  
   – The possible point-source nucleus warrants follow-up spectroscopy to assess emission-line diagnostics (e.g. [O III]/Hβ, [N II]/Hα) and confirm or rule out a low‐luminosity AGN.  
   – If this galaxy lies at z ≃ 0.05–0.1 (typical for similar angular sizes in wide‐field surveys), its exponential scale length would be of order 1–3 kpc, consistent with early‐type disk scaling relations.  
   – Future deep, multi‐band imaging could search for subtle disk substructure or low‐contrast tidal features; integral field spectroscopy could map its kinematics and stellar population gradients to refine the morphological and evolutionary classification.

Classify this galaxy by following the decision tree structure above.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The main system consists of two distinct galaxies in apparent close proximity (projected separation ≃15″). Their shapes and colors suggest an interacting pair rather than a chance alignment. The western component shows a disturbed, asymmetric envelope rather than a regular spiral pattern; the eastern component is compact, rounder and smoother, consistent with an early‐type (E/S0) morphology. Together they form an early‐stage merging system.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
- Western Galaxy (Disturbed Disk/Irregular)  
  • Envelope and Tidal Tail: A low‐surface-brightness extension (“tail”) stretches from the main body toward the west, curving slightly northward, characteristic of tidal stripping.  
  • Patchy Star‐Forming Regions: Several blue knots are embedded in the rim of the southern side of the envelope, indicative of H II regions triggered by the interaction.  
  • Color Gradient: The nucleus is moderately red (g–r ∼ 0.6), transitioning to bluer (g–r ∼ 0.3–0.4) outskirts, consistent with centrally concentrated older stars plus outside star formation.  
  • Surface Brightness Profile: The inner isophotes appear somewhat flattened (axial ratio b/a ≈ 0.7), though distorted by tidal forces; no clear bar structure is seen.  

- Eastern Galaxy (Early-Type/Compact)  
  • Smooth, Symmetric Core: Presents a bright, centrally peaked light profile with round isophotes (b/a > 0.9) out to ≃3″ radius, resembling an Sersic n ∼ 4 profile.  
  • Red Color: Uniformly yellow–orange (g–r ∼ 0.9), pointing to an older stellar population and little ongoing star formation.  
  • No Obvious Dust Lanes or Spiral Features: The absence of patchiness or lanes reinforces an S0/E classification.  

- Interaction Signatures  
  • Faint Bridge: A tenuous luminous bridge links the two nuclei along the line joining their centers, denoting material exchange or common tidal debris.  
  • Relative Orientation: The major axis of the disturbed western galaxy is roughly orthogonal to the nucleus–nucleus vector, a configuration often seen in early‐stage flyby interactions.  

- Field Objects / Artifacts  
  • Ghost/Reflection Trio at Right: Three compact, colored “blobs” aligned roughly vertical, with the top one distinctly red and two fainter greenish–reddish ghost images below, are best interpreted as internal reflections (ghosts) from a bright star outside the frame rather than physical companions or gravitationally lensed arcs.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- Dynamical State: The clear tidal tail, diffuse bridge, and asymmetric disk imply the system is past first close passage but not yet fully merged, with a mass ratio likely ∼1:2–1:3.  
- Star-Formation vs. Quenching: The western disk is undergoing interaction-induced star formation (blue knots), whereas the eastern early-type shows quiescence; continued gas inflow may eventually trigger nuclear activity or further starbursts.  
- Future Evolution: Over the next few 10^8 yr the system may settle into a more spheroidal remnant, with the larger stellar mass of the early‐type dominating and the disk stars of the spiral redistributed into shells or a diffuse halo.  
- Observational Notes: A follow-up integral‐field spectroscopy (e.g. with MUSE or KCWI) could map the kinematics of the tidal features and confirm any AGN signatures in the compact nucleus. Multiwavelength data (HI, CO, mid-IR) would quantify the gas content feeding star formation during the merger.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The central object is best described as an irregular, highly disturbed system, consistent with a late‐stage galaxy interaction or merger.  
- There is no clear, symmetric disk or bulge component; instead, the light is concentrated into multiple bright knots with diffuse emission bridging them.  
- The overall shape is non-axisymmetric and lacks the coherent spiral arm or smooth elliptical halo usually seen in isolated galaxies.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
- Bright Blue Knots  
  • Two dominant emission peaks (“knots”) are visible, separated by ~2–3 arcseconds (projected).  
  • Both knots are compact (FWHM ≲1″), exhibit a blue broadband color (strong in the “g” and “r” bands), and likely trace massive H II regions or unresolved clusters of O/B stars.  
  • Their elongations (major axes ~1.5″) are roughly aligned along a north–south axis, but each knot shows slightly different position angles, suggesting they are distinct galactic nuclei or massive starburst clumps.  
- Diffuse Bridge / Tidal Feature  
  • A faint, low-surface-brightness “bridge” of emission connects the two main knots, with a surface brightness ~24–25 mag arcsec⁻² in r: typical of tidal debris.  
  • This diffuse light extends to the southeast of the southern knot, forming a short, curved tail ~1″ long.  
- Faint Compact Sources  
  • Immediately north of the main pair is a redder, more compact object (~21.5 mag), with a round PSF and very little diffuse halo. Its color (r−i ≳0.8) and point-like appearance are consistent with a background early-type galaxy or a compact foreground star.  
  • To the east of the merger, at ~4″ separation, is a very faint, elongated smudge (~>25 mag arcsec⁻²) that may be an unrelated background galaxy or additional tidal debris.  
- Field Star  
  • In the upper left (northwest) corner of the frame is a round, diffraction‐limited white point (FWHM~0.8″), consistent with a foreground M‐type star (r~19 mag).  
- No Clear AGN Signature or Lensing  
  • There is no strong point‐source nuclear concentration or high‐contrast diffraction pattern to suggest an unobscured AGN.  
  • The geometry and symmetry of the features are inconsistent with a classic strong‐lensing configuration (no partial arcs around a central mass).

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- Starburst Trigger: The blue colors and clumpy morphology argue for a triggered starburst, likely induced by the close passage or coalescence of two gas-rich progenitors.  
- Redshift Estimate: Assuming typical H II region luminosities and apparent magnitudes (r~21–22 mag), the system may lie at z≈0.1–0.3. Spectroscopic follow-up (e.g., Hα, [O III] emission lines) would confirm its distance and star‐formation rate.  
- Merger Stage: The clear tidal bridge and nascent tail suggest an intermediate to late merger stage—after first pericentric passage but before full relaxation. The two brightness peaks could be the individual nuclei on the verge of coalescence.  
- Future Observations: Deeper imaging in the near-IR would help detect any obscured stellar bulge components, while integral-field spectroscopy could map velocity gradients and confirm interaction kinematics.

For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).

result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The primary object is a highly inclined (nearly edge-on) disk galaxy.  
- The light profile shows a pronounced central bulge embedded in an extended thin disk.  
- No obvious major disturbance, asymmetry, or double nucleus to suggest an ongoing major merger; the system is best classed as an edge-on spiral (Sa–Sb) or lenticular (S0) galaxy.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
 a) Central Bulge  
  • Morphology: Smooth, roughly elliptical isophotes, dominating the inner ∼5–10 arcsec.  
  • Color/Population: Orange–yellow hue indicates an older, metal–rich stellar population.  
  • Surface Brightness: Peak surface brightness exceeds that of the disk by ≳1 mag arcsec⁻² in the optical bands.  

 b) Thin Stellar Disk  
  • Extent & Orientation: Extends ≳30 arcsec on either side of the bulge along a PA ≈ 45° (NE–SW).  
  • Edge-on Appearance: The midplane remains straight with no prominent warp; vertical scale height is unresolved at the image’s ∼1 arcsec seeing.  
  • Color Gradient: Outskirts appear slightly bluer (toward greenish tones) than the bulge, consistent with radial population gradients.  

 c) Dust/Lane Candidates  
  • There is no sharply defined dark lane bisecting the bulge, but subtle mottling in the inner disk suggests patchy dust absorption.  
  • Any dust signature is weak; the disk light remains relatively uniform, arguing for a low dust mass or a dust layer thinner than the stellar scale height.  

 d) Star-Forming Regions & AGN  
  • No discrete H II-type clumps or blue knots are visible above the disk plane; current star formation must be at a low level or confined to an optically thick midplane.  
  • No central point-source spike or jet feature indicative of a luminous AGN.  

 e) Foreground/Background Objects  
  • A bright, blue point source ∼15 arcsec NW of the galaxy midplane is consistent with a foreground star (unresolved, high contrast in the blue channel).  
  • Several faint, compact red sources and small smudges scattered across the frame are likely background galaxies. None exhibit obvious lensing arcs or multiple images.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- The overall red–orange disk color and lack of significant dust lanes or star-forming knots suggest an evolved system, possibly a lenticular galaxy with residual, low-level star formation.  
- If placed at a typical intermediate redshift (z ≈ 0.05–0.1), the disk’s projected length of ∼60 arcsec corresponds to ∼50–100 kpc, implying a massive stellar disk.  
- The symmetric, undisturbed morphology argues against any recent major interaction; the galaxy may be dynamically relaxed in a low-density environment.  
- Follow-up spectroscopy (e.g., emission-line diagnostics) would test for a weak LINER/AGN component or residual star formation hidden by dust.  
- Deeper near-infrared imaging could reveal a faint bar or a thicker stellar component, clarifying the Sa versus S0 classification.

  • Several faint, compact red sources and small smudges scattered across the frame are likely background galaxies. None exhibit obvious lensing arcs or multiple images.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- The overall red–orange disk color and lack of significant dust lanes or star-forming knots suggest an evolved system, possibly a lenticular galaxy with residual, low-level star formation.  
- If placed at a typical intermediate redshift (z ≈ 0.05–0.1), the disk’s projected length of ∼60 arcsec corresponds to ∼50–100 kpc, implying a massive stellar disk.  
- The symmetric, undisturbed morphology argues against any recent major interaction; the galaxy may be dynamically relaxed in a low-density environment.  
- Follow-up spectroscopy (e.g., emission-line diagnostics) would test for a weak LINER/AGN component or residual star formation hidden by dust.  
- Deeper near-infrared imaging could reveal a faint bar or a thicker stellar component, clarifying the Sa versus S0 classification.

Classify this galaxy by following the decision tree structure above.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).

Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
• Highly‐inclined disk galaxy (inclination ≳ 80°), seen nearly edge-on.  
• The light profile is dominated by a flattened stellar disk with a modest central bulge.  
• No obvious second nucleus or large companion at comparable brightness; the system appears non‐interacting on large scales.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
• Stellar Disk  
  – Geometry: Thin, exponential‐type disk extending ∼20–30″ in projected semi-major axis.  
  – Color Structure: Inner ∼5″ appears yellow–orange (dominated by older, metal-rich populations); beyond that radius the disk transitions to a bluish hue, indicative of ongoing star formation in the outer regions.  
  – Flaring/Warp: The outermost isophotes on the southwest side show a slight vertical flare or warp at low surface brightness (μg ≳ 25 mag arcsec⁻²), suggesting either a mild tidal perturbation or a misaligned outer gas layer.  

• Bulge/Inner Component  
  – Morphology: A rounder, higher surface‐brightness core of radius ∼3–4″ with a de Vaucouleurs‐like profile.  
  – Color: Redder (g–r ≃ 0.6–0.7) than the surrounding disk, consistent with an older, more metal‐rich stellar population.  
  – No resolved bar structure is apparent, but the edge‐on view could mask a weak bar aligned along the line of sight.

• Dust and Extinction  
  – No single, sharp midplane dust lane is evident (as one often sees in very late‐type, high‐dust‐content galaxies).  
  – Subtle, patchy reddening visible in the inner ±2″ of the midplane, possibly tracing a low‐contrast dust layer or scattered light from HII regions.

• Star‐Forming Regions  
  – The bluish outer disk exhibits several compact knots of enhanced surface brightness (diameters ≲ 1″). These are consistent with Hα‐bright star‐forming complexes or young stellar associations.  
  – Their distribution is asymmetric, with a slight concentration on the northeast quadrant, potentially signaling localized gas accretion or minor disk asymmetry.

• Foreground/Background Objects  
  – A handful of point‐like sources scattered across the field with stellar PSFs and colors inconsistent with the galaxy’s disk—likely Milky Way foreground stars.  
  – A few faint, compact extended sources (r ≲ 1.5″) in the background, possibly distant galaxies seen through low‐extinction lines of sight.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Stellar Population Gradient: The pronounced color transition from red bulge to blue outer disk implies an inside‐out growth history, with older populations centrally concentrated and ongoing star formation at larger radii.  
• Disk Stability and Dynamics: The mild outer warp could trace a misaligned H I layer or the aftermath of a past minor merger/infall event (mass ratio ≲ 1:10). Kinematic mapping (e.g. via H I or CO) would test for anomalies in the rotation curve.  
• AGN Activity: No obvious nuclear point source or high‐surface‐brightness spike is visible in optical colors; any low‐luminosity AGN would require spectroscopy (e.g. BPT line diagnostics) to confirm.  
• Environment: The absence of a bright companion in the immediate vicinity and the regularity of the inner disk suggest a relatively isolated field galaxy. A wider‐field survey would clarify membership in any loose group.  
• Future Observations: Deep multi‐band imaging (including NIR) and integral‐field spectroscopy will refine the bulge/disk decomposition, dust content, and star‐formation rate distribution—and help quantify any subtle non‐axisymmetric features masked by the high inclination.

- artifact: Image appears to be a star, artifact, or defect rather than a galaxy

**STEP 2: Follow the appropriate branch based on Step 1**

**If SMOOTH:**
- Determine roundness: round, in-between, cigar-shaped, or not-mentioned

**If FEATURED-OR-DISK:**
- Determine if edge-on: edge-on-yes, edge-on-no, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-yes:**
- Determine bulge shape: boxy, none, rounded, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-no:**
- Determine if has spiral arms: has-spiral-arms-yes, has-spiral-arms-no, or not-mentioned
- If has spiral arms:
  - Determine spiral winding: tight, medium, loose, or not-mentioned
  - Determine arm count: 1, 2, 3, 4, more-than-4, cant-tell, or not-mentioned
- For all non-edge-on galaxies (regardless of spiral arms):
  - Determine bar strength: strong, weak, no, or not-mentioned
  - Determine bulge size: dominant, large, moderate, small, none, or not-mentioned

- minor-disturbance: Small distortions or asymmetries
- major-disturbance: Significant warping, tidal features, or distortions
- merger: Clear signs of ongoing merger or recent collision
- not-mentioned: The description does not mention anything about merging or disturbance

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • System type: A close‐pair interacting/merging system, likely a minor or intermediate–mass‐ratio merger.  
   • Primary galaxy (central object): Nearly circular, high‐surface‐brightness core with only a very low‐contrast, diffuse stellar envelope; overall appearance consistent with an early‐type (E0–E2) or bulge‐dominated S0.  
   • Secondary galaxy (northeast component): Elongated, disk‐like morphology with a compact nucleus and a single, prominent tidal tail or stellar plume; overall shape irregular–disturbed.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   2.1. Primary Galaxy  
     – Core: Bright, unresolved or marginally resolved nucleus (FWHM ≃ 1.2–1.5 arcsec), white–blue color indicative of either a young starburst or a low‐luminosity AGN continuum.  
     – Envelope: Faint, nearly circular light profile extending to ≃ 3–4 arcsec radius (∼ 5–7 kpc at z ≈ 0.1), with no obvious spiral arms, bars, or dust lanes.  
     – Possible tidal bridge: Very low‐surface‐brightness emission appears to link the primary core to the base of the secondary’s disk.  

   2.2. Secondary Galaxy  
     – Nucleus: Point‐like, blue–white core about 1 arcsec in diameter, ∼ 1 mag fainter than the primary nucleus in the same band.  
     – Disk/Body: Elongated structure ∼ 2–3 arcsec (3–5 kpc) along PA ≃ 50° E of N, slightly asymmetric with one edge more sharply defined.  
     – Tidal Tail: A single, narrow stellar plume extends ≃ 3–4 arcsec (5–7 kpc) to the northeast, broadening and fading in surface brightness by ∼ 2 mag arcsec⁻² relative to the nucleus; tail is aligned roughly along the galaxy’s major axis, suggestive of a prograde encounter.  

   2.3. Field Objects  
     – Foreground stars: Several red/orange, point‐like sources (e.g. the bright red object at the bottom of the frame) with diffraction‐limited PSFs and no associated extended emission.  
     – Background galaxies: A few very faint, small, redshifted galaxies (≲ 1 arcsec across) scattered around the periphery; no obvious multiple‐image configurations or lensing arcs.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – Interaction stage: The presence of a single, well‐defined tidal tail and the small nucleus‐to‐nucleus separation (≈ 3 arcsec) place the system in an early‐to‐mid merger phase, shortly after first pericentric passage.  
   – Star formation & AGN: Blue–white colors of both nuclei and the tail imply active star formation triggered by tidal torques; the compactness of the primary core could also signal a nascent AGN feeding burst. Spectroscopic follow‐up (e.g. Hα, [O III], continuum slopes) would distinguish between nuclear starburst and Seyfert/LINER activity.  
   – Mass ratio & fate: The luminosity ratio (primary : secondary ≃ 2–3 : 1) suggests a minor‐to‐intermediate merger. Over the next ∼ 500 Myr, dynamical friction and tidal stripping will likely disperse the secondary’s disk into shells or streams around the primary, eventually producing a more spheroidal remnant with residual fine‐structure.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   – The central object is best classified as a low-inclination disc galaxy, most consistent with an S/Sb—type spiral.  It shows a dominant, nearly circular bulge embedded in a smooth, faint stellar disc.  There is no obvious large-scale bar or well-defined grand-design spiral pattern at this resolution; the outer isophotes are roughly elliptical (axial ratio b/a ≃ 0.8) with a major-axis position angle of ∼135° E of N.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a. Bulge and Inner Disc  
     • A high-surface-brightness central bulge: round, white in optical colour, extended (FWHM ≈ 5″–6″) rather than pointlike (no clear AGN psf).  
     • Surrounding bulge is a low-contrast, featureless stellar disc with a mild radial colour gradient—slightly bluer at R ≳ 6″.  

   b. Off-nuclear Star-forming Complex  
     • A compact, bright knot located ≃5″ northeast of the bulge centre, with bluish-white colour and peak surface brightness comparable to the bulge outskirts.  
     • Likely a giant H II region or a minor satellite/dwarf in the process of merging—its compactness (∼2″ FWHM) and blue colour favour intense, localized star formation.  

   c. Secondary Blue Knot  
     • A fainter (≈2× lower surface brightness) blue point located midway between the bulge and the northeast knot.  
     • Candidate young stellar cluster or smaller star-forming clump within the disc plane.  

   d. Foreground/Background Objects  
     • To the north (∼8″–12″ above centre) two yellow–orange, extended sources with de Vaucouleurs-like profiles: likely background early-type galaxies or group members unassociated with the disc.  
     • A blue point source ≃15″ west of centre: consistent with a foreground Milky Way star (stellar psf, bluish colour).  

   e. Lack of Strong Tidal or Dust Features  
     • No prominent dust lanes or filamentary absorption visible against the bulge light.  
     • The disc is largely undisturbed except for the northeast knot—no long tidal tails, plumes or shell structures canonically indicative of a major merger.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – The overall symmetry of the bulge + disc and absence of large-scale distortions argue against a recent major merger. The prominent off-nuclear knot, however, together with the slight warp of the outer isophotes, suggests a minor interaction or infall of a gas-rich dwarf, which may be driving localized starburst activity.  
   – Broadband colours (white central bulge transitioning to bluish knots) imply a mixed stellar population: an older, metal-rich bulge and younger, massive O/B stars in the off-centre complexes.  
   – No unambiguous sign of an active galactic nucleus (no central point-source spike, no jet-like structures). If an AGN is present, it must be low luminosity or heavily obscured.  
   – The two red objects to the north likely reside at higher redshift (z ≳ 0.3) and are chance projections; their presence hints that the disc galaxy may lie in a richer line-of-sight environment but is not necessarily a group member.  
   – Future follow-up: integral-field spectroscopy could map kinematics of the off-centre knot to confirm merger status and measure metallicities of the star-forming clumps relative to the bulge.

result:

Its light profile shows a bright, relatively compact central bulge embedded in a thinner, more extended stellar disk. The absence of clearly resolved spiral structure (arms) in projection and only very subtle color gradients suggests either an early-type spiral (Sa–Sb) viewed edge-on or a lenticular (S0) system.  
- Below the main disk, at a projected separation of ∼10–15″, lies a smaller, more spheroidal system with a smooth, elliptical isophotal shape and a uniformly yellowish hue, consistent with an E or S0 galaxy; there is no obvious disk or dust lane associated with it.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
- Edge-on Disk Galaxy (Primary)  
  • Bulge: A central, nearly round bulge dominates the inner ∼5–6″, with a yellowish color indicating an evolved stellar population. Bulge-to-disk light ratio appears moderate (B/D ∼0.3–0.5).  
  • Disk: Extends ∼20″ along its major axis. The outer isophotes flare slightly (“warped” appearance) on both ends, suggestive of a mild warp or tidal disturbance. No dark mid-plane dust lane is sharply defined, but slight reddening near the midplane hints at a diffuse dust component.  
  • Warping/Tidal Feature: The southwestern edge of the disk bends upward by a few arcseconds relative to the main midplane, while the northeastern edge shows a complementary downward flare. This symmetry is characteristic of an S-shaped warp, possibly induced by a past minor interaction.  
  • Star-forming Regions: The disk shows no bright, compact blue knots; the overall color is yellow-white, consistent with low present star‐formation activity or an aging disk.  
  • AGN/Point Source: No central point source or jet‐like features are detected at the nucleus; the surface-brightness profile is smooth through the center.  

- Companion-candidate Elliptical (Secondary)  
  • Morphology: Nearly round to mildly oblate spheroid, ∼6″ in diameter, with a smooth radial brightness profile (Sérsic n ≳3).  
  • Color: Uniformly yellow, lacking blue substructure or dust features.  
  • Association: Its projected proximity and similar coloration raise the possibility of physical association (group member) rather than a chance background object; however, no tidal bridge or distortion is evident.

- Field Objects  
  • Several faint, red, point-like sources scattered across the frame—likely foreground M dwarfs or unresolved background galaxies.  
  • No obvious strong lensing arcs or multiple‐image configurations are observed around the main galaxy.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- Interaction Scenario: The symmetric warp of the primary disk, combined with the presence of a nearby spheroidal companion, is consistent with either a weak tidal encounter or ongoing secular evolution in a group environment. If the two galaxies share a similar redshift, even a low‐mass flyby could induce the observed warp.  
- Stellar Populations & Activity: The integrated yellowish color of both systems points toward evolved, predominantly intermediate‐to‐old stellar populations with suppressed current star formation (SFR ≲0.1 M⊙/yr).  
- Dynamical Implications: The warp amplitude and lack of significant star formation suggest that any interaction is neither recent enough nor strong enough to trigger a major starburst, but may be sufficient to torque the outer disk. Alternatively, misalignment between disk and dark‐matter halo angular momentum could produce a similar warp without a companion.  
- Future Observations: Deep, multi‐band imaging (especially in the near-IR for dust tracing and in Hα for residual star formation) plus spectroscopy to measure relative redshifts and rotation curves would clarify the nature of the warp and the dynamical relationship between the two galaxies.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • The central object is a nearly round, high–surface‐brightness system with smooth, concentric isophotes and no obvious spiral structure or dust lanes. Its light profile is characteristic of a de Vaucouleurs (r¹/⁴) law, consistent with an early–type (E0–E1) galaxy.  
   • Encircling this main galaxy is a nearly complete, circular ring (and hints of a fainter, larger‐radius ring), suggestive not of a collisional ring phenomenon but of strong gravitational lensing: an almost ideal “Einstein ring.”  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   A. Central Point Source  
     – Unresolved nucleus with a steep brightness cusp; the PSF‐like core implies either an active galactic nucleus (AGN) or a compact starburst, though the overall color (yellow–white) favors an old stellar population plus possible low‐level AGN.  
     – Peak surface brightness exceeds that of the ring by ≳2 magnitudes, and the isophotes inside ∼1″ are nearly circular (axis ratio ≳0.95).  
   B. Primary Ring (“Einstein Ring”)  
     – Radius ∼4–5″ centered on the deflector; width ∼1″ with remarkably uniform surface brightness around >270° of azimuth.  
     – The ring’s color is slightly bluer (green-white) than the lens, hinting at a background star‐forming galaxy spectrum redshifted into the observed bands.  
     – No pronounced clumpiness or knotty H II regions, consistent with lensing of a fairly smooth background disk rather than bright individual star clusters.  
   C. Secondary/Outer Arc  
     – A much fainter, broader halo at ∼7–8″ radius, visible at lower S/N. May trace either higher‐order lensing images of the same source or a second source at a different redshift.  
     – Patchy and incomplete (spanning ∼120° in the southern quadrant), requiring deeper imaging for confirmation.  
   D. Field Sources & Companions  
     – To the southeast and northwest of the ring lie several point‐like objects (color indices range from greenish to bluish) consistent with foreground stars or small satellite galaxies in the lens environment.  
     – A red-orange compact source 6–7″ northeast of center lacks clear morphological structure; could be a cluster member or a chance projection.  
     – No obvious tidal debris or low‐surface‐brightness shells around the central galaxy beyond the ring system.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Lens Model Implications: The high degree of circular symmetry in the ring implies a nearly isotropic mass distribution (ellipticity ≲0.1) and minimal external shear (γ ≲0.02). A single‐plane lens at z ≈ 0.2–0.4 with a velocity dispersion of 250–300 km/s could reproduce the ∼5″ Einstein radius.  
   • Source Properties: The uniform brightness of the ring argues for an extended background disk/early‐type galaxy rather than a quasar point source, though a weak AGN continuum could still be present. The possible secondary arc suggests a complex source or multi‐plane lensing.  
   • Environment: The presence of nearby red/orange and bluish companions hints at a small group or poor cluster environment, which may contribute minor shear and convergence to the lens potential.  
   • Astrophysical Use: This system is an excellent candidate for detailed lens modeling to map the dark matter halo profile of the central elliptical, to measure H₀ via time delays if an AGN is present, and to study the unlensed background galaxy’s morphology once de-lensed.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   – The principal object is a nearly face-on disk galaxy with a well-defined, high-surface-brightness central bulge and a low-bulge-to-disk ratio.  
   – Hubble type is best described as an unbarred spiral, roughly SA(r)bc–c: no obvious bar, a weak inner ring or pseudo-ring, and loosely wound, flocculent arms.  
   – The outer isophotes are fairly circular, indicating an inclination ≲ 30°, and extend to a radius of ∼15–18″ before surface‐brightness drops to the background.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a) Central Bulge / Nucleus  
     • Very bright, slightly elongated core (semi–major axis ≲ 5″) with a nearly stellar PSF in the g-band; white color (g–r ≃ 0.3) suggests a mixed old + young population or a low-luminosity AGN.  
     • No obvious double nucleus or off-center component to suggest a recent major merger.  
   b) Spiral Arms & Star-forming Regions  
     • Two to three primary spiral arms emerge from an inner pseudo-ring at ∼6–8″ radius.  
     • Arms are blue in the composite (g–r ≲ 0.0), clumpy in structure, and riddled with discrete H II–region knots (typical clump size ∼2–3″).  
     • Arms extend out to ∼15–18″ with a surface-brightness contrast of Δμ ≃ 1.5–2 mag arcsec⁻² relative to the interarm disk.  
   c) Dust & Extinction  
     • No prominent dust lanes crossing the bulge or arms; extinction features, if present, are below SDSS detection limits in this image.  
   d) Nearby/Foreground/Background Objects  
     • A red point source (g–r ≃ 1.2) lies ∼30″ SW of the galaxy center – consistent with a foreground M-dwarf star.  
     • An orange, star-like object ∼10″ ENE of the galaxy core (g–r ≃ 0.8) is likely another foreground star.  
     • Further east are two faint, extended smudges (one green-tinted, one yellowish) at ∼20–30″ separation; these are background galaxies at higher redshift.  
   e) Interaction / Tidal Features / Lensing  
     • No tidal tails, streams, or shell features above the noise floor.  
     • No arclets, radial or tangential distortions indicative of strong gravitational lensing by the central galaxy.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – Photometry (SDSS g,r,i composite) suggests the disk is gas–rich and actively forming stars, with a global star-formation rate of order 1 M⊙ yr⁻¹ (scaling from Hα–equivalent clump luminosities).  
   – At a nominal redshift z ∼ 0.05 (Dₗ ≃ 200 Mpc), the 36″ diameter corresponds to ∼35 kpc, typical for an Sc‐class spiral.  
   – The bright, compact nucleus could host a weak AGN or LINER; optical spectroscopy (e.g. BPT diagnostics) would be needed to confirm nuclear activity.  
   – The symmetry and low asymmetry index (A ≲ 0.1) argue against any recent major merger; the galaxy appears to be in a secularly evolving, isolated environment.
