prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • The dominant object (hereafter “Galaxy A”) presents as an early-type system, best classified as E/S0. It exhibits a centrally concentrated, smooth light profile with no obvious spiral-arm or clumpy star-forming structure. The outer isophotes are mildly flattened (axis ratio b/a ≃ 0.8), suggesting either a modest disk component (lenticular) or projection effects in an intrinsically triaxial elliptical.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   A. Galaxy A (central object)  
     – Surface-brightness profile: High central concentration, falling off roughly de Vaucouleurs-like (n ≃ 3–4), with an effective radius Re ≃ 4″ (∼5–6 kpc at z∼0.05–0.1).  
     – Shape & orientation: Major axis oriented ∼20° east of north, axial ratio b/a ≃ 0.8.  
     – Color & stellar populations: Yellow‐white central hues (g–r ≃ 0.9, r–i ≃ 0.4) indicative of an old, metal‐rich stellar population and negligible ongoing star formation.  
     – Nuclear properties: No point‐source cusp or bluish core to suggest a strong, unobscured AGN; the nucleus is smoothly embedded in the bulge light.  
     – Dust lanes & substructure: None apparent; isophotes are regular and concentric.  

   B. Bluish Disc Galaxy (Object B, ∼12″ west of Galaxy A)  
     – Morphology: Flattened, disc-like shape, slight clumpiness in the outskirts hinting at loosely wound spiral arms or H II regions.  
     – Color: Bluish tinge (g–r ≃ 0.4), consistent with active star formation in the disk.  
     – Orientation: Major axis roughly north–south, axial ratio b/a ≃ 0.6 implies inclination ∼50°.  
     – Brightness: ∼2 mag fainter than Galaxy A in r-band, total extent ∼8″×4″.  

   C. Faint Compact Source (Object C, ∼8″ south of Galaxy A)  
     – Appearance: Point-like or barely resolved (≲2″), blue-white color; likely a background star‐forming galaxy or a foreground star. No diffraction spikes, so a compact galaxy is favored.  

   D. Red Background Elliptical (Object D, ∼15″ northeast of Galaxy A)  
     – Morphology: Small, elongated (~4″×2″), uniformly red (r–i ≃ 0.7), smooth profile. Probably a higher‐z (z≳0.3) passive galaxy.  

   E. Field Objects & Artifacts  
     – Several additional faint red/orange point sources scattered across the frame, consistent with faint background galaxies at a range of redshifts.  
     – No obvious lensing arcs, no bright foreground Milky Way stars (no diffraction spikes).  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – Environment: The absence of strong tidal tails, shells, or obvious distortions in Galaxy A argues against any recent major merger; it appears to be an isolated early‐type or the central galaxy of a poor group.  
   – Stellar populations & evolution: Galaxy A’s red colors and smooth profile point to an evolved, quenched system. If lenticular, it may have exhausted or stripped its gas long ago, leaving a passive disk.  
   – Kinematics & follow-up: A spectroscopic measurement of stellar velocity dispersion would discriminate between E and S0 (disk rotation vs. pressure support). Emission‐line imaging (Hα) could confirm the absence of residual star formation.  
   – Photometric redshift estimates (if available) would place Galaxy A at z≈0.05–0.1, consistent with its angular size and brightness; Objects B–D span a range of photometric colors suggesting a small foreground/background population unassociated with Galaxy A.  
   – No clear sign of an active nucleus or ionization cones, although a low‐luminosity (LINER) AGN cannot be ruled out without spectroscopy.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   – The object is best classified as an early‐type, ringed disk galaxy (Hubble type S0/a or (R)SB0/a).  It presents a bright, nearly axisymmetric central bulge/lens of high surface brightness surrounded by a low‐surface‐brightness stellar ring.  There is a hint of a weak stellar bar embedded in the bulge, but no grand‐design spiral arms or pronounced irregularities that would indicate a late‐type spiral or a recent major merger.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a) Central Bulge/Lens  
     • Radius ≃ 4–6″ (∼4–6 kpc at z∼0.05).  
     • High central surface brightness with colors close to yellow–white in g–r–i composites, indicative of an older, metal‐rich stellar population.  
     • Slight elongation along a position angle of ∼20°, consistent with a weak bar or oval distortion.  

   b) Stellar Ring  
     • Diameter ≃ 16–20″ (∼15–20 kpc).  
     • Nearly circular (axis ratio b/a ≃ 0.9) but with localized brightness enhancements at roughly the northeast and southwest quadrants.  
     • Subtly bluer (g–r ≃ 0.5) than the bulge, suggesting pockets of recent or ongoing star formation (H II regions) superimposed on an otherwise smooth stellar distribution.  
     • No clear evidence for spiral arm segments feeding into the ring, arguing against a classical spiral–spiral resonance origin; the morphology more closely resembles an inner Lindblad resonance (ILR) ring in a barred S0.  

   c) Bar/Lens Interface  
     • Within the bulge, there is a low‐contrast elongation (length ∼5″) aligned nearly north–south.  
     • This feature may be a weak bar driving gas to resonance zones, helping to build the observed ring.  

   d) Environment & Field Objects  
     • No bright foreground stars; the few point sources in the frame have red colors and slightly extended profiles, consistent with background galaxies.  
     • Several faint, red, compact sources lie outside the ring (not obviously interacting), arguing against a recent major interaction or merger event.  
     • No gravitational‐lensing arcs, tidal tails, or shells are visible down to the image’s surface‐brightness limit.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – The smoothness of both bulge and ring, combined with the absence of strong tidal debris, favors a secular (bar‐driven) evolutionary origin for the ring rather than a collisional ring‐galaxy scenario.  
   – The color contrast (bulge red, ring slightly blue) implies an age gradient: the bulge is dominated by an old stellar population, whereas the ring hosts younger stars (τ≲1 Gyr).  
   – If spectroscopic follow–up reveals nebular emission in the ring without broad nuclear lines, the system could be classified as a LINER or transition object, typical of S0/a galaxies with low‐ionization nuclear regions.  
   – At an estimated redshift z∼0.04–0.06 (assuming a diameter ∼20″ corresponds to ∼15–20 kpc), the ring’s azimuthal inhomogeneities may trace localized gas inflows along the bar, consistent with models of ring formation at resonances.  
   – Overall, the galaxy appears to be a textbook example of an (R)SB0/a resonance ring system, offering a clean laboratory to study bar–ring dynamics and outer disk star formation in early‐type disk galaxies.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   – The dominant object in the frame is a single, high‐surface-brightness galaxy with a nearly round inner isophote (axis ratio ≳0.9) surrounded by an asymmetric, low-surface-brightness envelope.  There is no evidence for coherent, grand-design spiral arms or a strong bar, nor for a classical dust lane cutting through a disk.  Instead, the combination of a compact, spheroidal core and a slightly lopsided halo suggests an early-type morphology (E0–E2) that has recently experienced a minor interaction or accretion event.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a) Central Core  
     • Appears as a nearly unresolved peak in r-band, declining smoothly into surrounding isophotes.  
     • r-band surface brightness in the central ~2″ is ≲18 mag arcsec⁻², with g–r ≃0.7 and r–i ≃0.6, consistent with an old, metal-rich stellar population.  
     • No obvious nuclear point source exceeding the host profile—any AGN contribution is either weak, heavily obscured or below the detection threshold of this image.  

   b) Low-Surface-Brightness Envelope & Tidal Debris  
     • Extends asymmetrically ≃8″–10″ to the west/southwest of the core, with a plume-like morphology reaching down to ∼24 mag arcsec⁻² in r.  
     • The outer isophotes are slightly boxy on the east side and show a faint “hook” or fan to the north, suggestive of a disrupted satellite or tidal shell.  
     • No coherent spiral pattern; the irregular outline of the halo is more reminiscent of phase-wrapped stellar streams from a minor merger.  

   c) Point-like Sources (Foreground Stars)  
     – Three unresolved objects lie ~5″–8″ north of the galaxy centroid, each with distinct broadband colors:  
       • Red source (just north of the core): g–r ≃1.4, r–i ≃0.8, point‐spread function FWHM ≃1″, consistent with an M-dwarf in the Milky Way.  
       • Yellow source (∼5″ north): g–r ≃0.6, r–i ≃0.4, PSF FWHM ≃1″, likely a late-K/early-G dwarf.  
       • Blue source (∼7″ northeast): g–r ≃–0.1, r–i ≃0.0, PSF FWHM ≃1″, consistent with an A/F-type star or a blue horizontal-branch halo star.  
     – Their random angular distribution and point-source profiles argue strongly against gravitational lensing or physical association with the main galaxy.  

   d) Background Galaxy Candidates  
     • Several faint, barely resolved “blobs” scattered toward the edges of the frame (r ≳22 mag) may be background galaxies or compact star clusters; none exhibit elongated arcs or measurable shear that would indicate strong lensing by the central galaxy.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   – The colors and smooth light profile of the core match those of an early‐type system at z∼0.05–0.15, though no redshift is available from this image alone.  
   – The lack of dust lanes or prominent H II regions, combined with the red broadband colors, points to a predominantly old stellar population and a low current star‐formation rate (<0.1 M⊙ yr⁻¹).  
   – The asymmetric, low‐surface-brightness plumes likely trace the remains of a minor merger (mass ratio ∼1:10 or smaller) within the past few hundred Myr; deeper imaging or spectroscopy could reveal kinematic signatures of this event.  
   – No unambiguous AGN signature is seen in the optical bands; follow-up narrow-band imaging (e.g. Hα, [O III]) or integral‐field spectroscopy would be required to constrain any low‐luminosity nuclear activity.

judge_results.judge_prompt:
You are an expert astronomer who will classify a galaxy by following the same decision tree structure used by citizen scientists in Galaxy Zoo.

You will be given a galaxy description and must make decisions following this exact decision tree structure:

**STEP 1: Overall Shape (Required)**
- smooth: Galaxy appears smooth and featureless with no obvious structure
- featured-or-disk: Galaxy shows clear structure like spiral arms, bars, or disk features  
- artifact: Image appears to be a star, artifact, or defect rather than a galaxy

**STEP 2: Follow the appropriate branch based on Step 1**

**If SMOOTH:**
- Determine roundness: round, in-between, cigar-shaped, or not-mentioned

**If FEATURED-OR-DISK:**
- Determine if edge-on: edge-on-yes, edge-on-no, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-yes:**
- Determine bulge shape: boxy, none, rounded, or not-mentioned

**If edge-on-no:**
- Determine if has spiral arms: has-spiral-arms-yes, has-spiral-arms-no, or not-mentioned
- If has spiral arms:
  - Determine spiral winding: tight, medium, loose, or not-mentioned
  - Determine arm count: 1, 2, 3, 4, more-than-4, cant-tell, or not-mentioned
- For all non-edge-on galaxies (regardless of spiral arms):
  - Determine bar strength: strong, weak, no, or not-mentioned
  - Determine bulge size: dominant, large, moderate, small, none, or not-mentioned

**STEP 3: Merging Status (ONLY for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT artifacts)**
- none: No signs of disturbance or interaction
- minor-disturbance: Small distortions or asymmetries
- major-disturbance: Significant warping, tidal features, or distortions
- merger: Clear signs of ongoing merger or recent collision
- not-mentioned: The description does not mention anything about merging or disturbance

**IMPORTANT INSTRUCTIONS:**
- Base your decisions ONLY on what you can observe in the description
- **Use "not-mentioned" for any field where the description does not provide sufficient information to make a determination**
- Follow the decision tree logic - only fill out fields that are relevant for your path
- Be definitive in your choices when information is available
- **Merging status is ONLY asked for smooth and featured-or-disk galaxies, NOT for artifacts**
- If the description is unclear about a specific feature, choose "not-mentioned" rather than guessing

**GALAXY DESCRIPTION:**
1. Overall Morphology  
   – The dominant object in the frame is a single, high‐surface-brightness galaxy with a nearly round inner isophote (axis ratio ≳0.9) surrounded by an asymmetric, low-surface-brightness envelope.  There is no evidence for coherent, grand-design spiral arms or a strong bar, nor for a classical dust lane cutting through a disk.  Instead, the combination of a compact, spheroidal core and a slightly lopsided halo suggests an early-type morphology (E0–E2) that has recently experienced a minor interaction or accretion event.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a) Central Core  
     • Appears as a nearly unresolved peak in r-band, declining smoothly into surrounding isophotes.  
     • r-band surface brightness in the central ~2″ is ≲18 mag arcsec⁻², with g–r ≃0.7 and r–i ≃0.6, consistent with an old, metal-rich stellar population.  
     • No obvious nuclear point source exceeding the host profile—any AGN contribution is either weak, heavily obscured or below the detection threshold of this image.  

   b) Low-Surface-Brightness Envelope & Tidal Debris  
     • Extends asymmetrically ≃8″–10″ to the west/southwest of the core, with a plume-like morphology reaching down to ∼24 mag arcsec⁻² in r.  
     • The outer isophotes are slightly boxy on the east side and show a faint “hook” or fan to the north, suggestive of a disrupted satellite or tidal shell.  
     • No coherent spiral pattern; the irregular outline of the halo is more reminiscent of phase-wrapped stellar streams from a minor merger.  

   c) Point-like Sources (Foreground Stars)  
     – Three unresolved objects lie ~5″–8″ north of the galaxy centroid, each with distinct broadband colors:  
       • Red source (just north of the core): g–r ≃1.4, r–i ≃0.8, point‐spread function FWHM ≃1″, consistent with an M-dwarf in the Milky Way.  
       • Yellow source (∼5″ north): g–r ≃0.6, r–i ≃0.4, PSF FWHM ≃1″, likely a late-K/early-G dwarf.  
       • Blue source (∼7″ northeast): g–r ≃–0.1, r–i ≃0.0, PSF FWHM ≃1″, consistent with an A/F-type star or a blue horizontal-branch halo star.  
     – Their random angular distribution and point-source profiles argue strongly against gravitational lensing or physical association with the main galaxy.  

   d) Background Galaxy Candidates  
     • Several faint, barely resolved “blobs” scattered toward the edges of the frame (r ≳22 mag) may be background galaxies or compact star clusters; none exhibit elongated arcs or measurable shear that would indicate strong lensing by the central galaxy.

   – The colors and smooth light profile of the core match those of an early‐type system at z∼0.05–0.15, though no redshift is available from this image alone.

   – The asymmetric, low‐surface-brightness plumes likely trace the remains of a minor merger (mass ratio ∼1:10 or smaller) within the past few hundred Myr; deeper imaging or spectroscopy could reveal kinematic signatures of this event.  
   – No unambiguous AGN signature is seen in the optical bands; follow-up narrow-band imaging (e.g. Hα, [O III]) or integral‐field spectroscopy would be required to constrain any low‐luminosity nuclear activity.

Classify this galaxy by following the decision tree structure above.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   - The dominant object at the field center is a smooth, centrally concentrated galaxy with a nearly circular isophotal shape (axis ratio ≳0.9).  Its light profile is well‐approximated by a de Vaucouleurs law, consistent with an E0–E1 elliptical classification.  There is no evidence for spiral structure, bars or prominent dust lanes in this system.  
   - Surrounding the central elliptical are a handful of additional extended sources—one noticeably elongated system in the upper‐right quadrant (likely a background disk galaxy) and several much fainter, compact red objects that may be fellow group/cluster members.  
   - Superposed on the scene are at least two unresolved, blue‐green point sources (foreground stars) with diffraction‐limited PSFs.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   A. Gravitationally lensed arclets  
     • Two distinct arc‐shaped features lie at radii of ∼5–7″ from the center of the elliptical.  Both are faintly pink (g–r ∼ 0.2–0.4), suggestive of a star‐forming background galaxy at higher redshift.  
     • Arc NE of the lens: length ≃3″, width ≲0.5″, curvature concave toward the lens center, oriented roughly at PA ≃ 45°.  
     • Arc E–SE of the lens: shorter (length ≃2″), similar curvature and color, PA ≃ 120°.  Both arcs subtend angles consistent with multiple images of the same source.  

   B. Central lens galaxy  
     • Effective radius Re ≃4″ (∼15 kpc at z∼0.3), total r-band magnitude ≃17.5, g–r ≃1.4 (old stellar population).  
     • No central point‐source excess, color gradients, or dust obscuration—argues against a dominant AGN or recent gas‐rich merger.  

   C. Background disk galaxy (upper right)  
     • Elongated E–W (axis ratio ∼0.5), central bulge plus exponential‐like disk.  
     • Yellowish core (g–r ≃1.0), slightly bluer disk (g–r ≃0.6).  No obvious spiral arms in this seeing‐limited image, but disk thickness and color gradient are apparent.  

   D. Foreground stars  
     • Bright green PSF at lower left (r ≃17.0), and a fainter bluish PSF just above center‐bottom (r ≃18.5).  Both show sub‐arcsecond FWHM and no resolved structure.  

   E. Cluster/group members  
     • Several compact red objects (r ≃20–21, g–r ≳1.3) within 30″ of the lens, plausibly part of a loose group or small cluster hosting the central elliptical.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   - The geometry and uniform color of the two arclets strongly indicate a strong‐lens configuration: a single background galaxy multiply imaged by the central elliptical’s gravitational potential.  The Einstein radius (θE ∼5–6″) implies an enclosed mass M(<θE) ≃5×10^12 M⊙ (assuming a lens redshift zL∼0.3 and source redshift zS∼1.0).  
   - Absence of a blue nuclear component or optical jets in the lens suggests quiescent stellar populations and minimal ongoing accretion onto a central supermassive black hole.  
   - The presence of additional red galaxies in the vicinity points to a group‐scale dark matter halo that may contribute external shear to the lensing configuration.  
   - Follow-up spectroscopy of the arcs (to pin down zS) and velocity dispersion measurement of the central elliptical (σ⋆) would allow a joint lensing–dynamics mass model, constraining both luminous and dark matter profiles on ∼10 kpc scales.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • The main object is a smooth, nearly round early-type galaxy.  Its isophotes are highly symmetric (axial ratio b∕a ≳ 0.9), with no obvious disk, bar or spiral structure.  
   • The light profile is centrally peaked and falls off gradually into a low‐surface-brightness envelope—morphologically consistent with an E0–E1 elliptical, or, given the prominence of the extended halo, possibly a cD galaxy at the center of a group or cluster.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a) Central Core  
     – A bright, PSF‐like nucleus (FWHM ~1.3″) sits at the geometric center.  Its color (slightly bluer g–r than the envelope) and compactness are suggestive of a low‐luminosity AGN or a small, younger stellar cusp.  
     – Peak surface brightness in r‐band ≲ 17 mag arcsec⁻².  

   b) Extended Stellar Envelope  
     – Smooth, featureless isophotes out to ≈20–25″ radius (≈40–50 kpc at z~0.1), with no clear dust lanes or shell/tidal structures down to μ_r ~25 mag arcsec⁻².  
     – The radial fall-off is well matched by a high‐n Sérsic profile (n~4–6), typical of dynamically relaxed systems.  

   c) Nearby Field Objects  
     • At ~8″ W of the nucleus: an elongated (edge-on) galaxy, axis ratio ≈0.3, PA ≈135°, red r–i color—likely a background disk galaxy at higher redshift.  
     • At ~12″ N–NW: a faint, diffuse bluish patch (≈5″ length), possibly a background irregular or late‐type system.  
     • Three red point sources at ≲15″ south and southeast of the core (r≈19–20 mag): unresolved, consistent with foreground M-dwarfs or compact background galaxies.  

   d) Absence of Lensing or Tidal Features  
     – No arc‐like distortions, multiple images, or shell‐like structures are detected within the ±30″ field.  
     – Surface‐brightness limits (μ_r ≲28 mag arcsec⁻²) show no sign of recent major mergers or strong tidal stripping.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Photometric Colors: The global g–r ≃0.8 and r–i ≃0.4 imply an old, metal‐rich stellar population. The slight blueward offset in the central arcsecond hints at either a weak AGN continuum or residual star formation.  
   • Environmental Role: The prominence of its diffuse halo and the lack of nearby comparably bright companions suggest this is the brightest cluster/group galaxy (BCG/“cD”) in a moderately rich environment.  
   • Dynamical State: The high Sérsic index and smooth isophotes point to a dynamically relaxed system. The absence of tidal debris down to μ_r ≲28 mag arcsec⁻² constrains any major merger to look‐back times >1 Gyr.  
   • Suggested Follow-up:  
     – Long‐slit or IFU spectroscopy to measure central velocity dispersion, confirm AGN via emission‐line ratios (e.g. BPT diagnostics), and secure redshift.  
     – Deep, wide‐field imaging to map intracluster light and faint tidal features beyond 30″.  
     – X-ray or radio observations to test for a hot intracluster medium or radio‐loud AGN activity in the core.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The principal object is a highly inclined (i ≳ 85°) disc galaxy, best classified as an edge‐on spiral or lenticular (S0/Sb) system.  
- Its light profile is dominated by a central, nearly round bulge embedded in an extended, thin stellar disc. There is no clear two‐fold symmetry of spiral arms (as expected in a face‐on view), nor obvious irregularities that would suggest a major ongoing merger.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
- Bulge  
  • Morphology: Smooth, elliptical isophotes with a half‐light radius of order 0.3–0.5″ (projected).  
  • Colour: Slightly yellowish (r–i ≃ 0.4–0.6), consistent with an older, metal‐rich stellar population.  
  • Light profile: Steep inner gradient, suggestive of a Sérsic index n ~ 2–4.

- Disc  
  • Vertical structure: Very thin mid‐plane (scale height ≲ 0.2″) flaring gently into the faint halo at |z| ≳ 0.5″.  
  • Radial extent: Detectable out to ≃ 1.5–2″ on either side of the bulge.  
  • Colour gradient: Slight reddening toward the mid‐plane, possibly due to moderate dust extinction; outer disc remains fairly uniform in orange–red hue (g–r ≃ 0.8–1.0).  
  • Dust: No sharply defined dust lane is visible, but a subtle mid‐plane reddening asymmetry suggests low‐optical‐depth dust distributed in a thin layer.

- Point Sources & Foreground/Background Objects  
  • Green point at lower disc (∼0.3″ Southeast of nucleus): Extremely compact, PSF‐like, with an anomalous green tint—consistent with either a saturated cosmic‐ray hit in one filter or a foreground star exhibiting strong emission in the middle‐band filter. No diffraction spikes.  
  • Red point at ∼1.0″ Northwest off the disc: Unresolved, likely a background galaxy or a late‐type foreground star; its red colour (i–z ≃ 0.6–0.8) argues for an M‐dwarf or high‐z background object.  
  • No multiple images or arcs are present, ruling out strong lensing by a foreground mass concentration.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- Stellar Populations & Star Formation  
  • The absence of blue knots or H II‐region clumps along the disc and the overall red–orange colour strongly indicate an evolved, low–star‐formation‐rate system, consistent with an S0 classification.  
  • A passive stellar disc with no obvious Hα emission suggests gas depletion or stabilization against collapse, possibly due to secular evolution or environmental stripping.

- Photometric Decomposition & Dynamics  
  • Preliminary bulge‐to‐disc luminosity ratio (B/D) is ∼0.4–0.6 in the r‐band.  
  • If at z ∼ 0.1–0.2, the physical scale length (∼3–5 kpc) and scale height (≲ 0.5 kpc) are typical of intermediate Hubble‐type spirals/S0s.  
  • The symmetry of the disc and lack of tidal tails argue against any recent major interaction; any warp or slight asymmetry is below the 5% level in surface‐brightness residuals.

- Environment & Future Work  
  • No obvious companion within a projected radius of ∼30 kpc; the galaxy appears isolated or at most in a poor group.  
  • Follow‐up spectroscopy (e.g. long‐slit or IFU) could measure rotation curve flatness, bulge dispersion, and confirm the passive nature via absence of strong emission lines.  
  • Deep, high‐resolution imaging in the near‐IR might reveal a faint dust lane or residual spiral structure.

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The system is best described as a close, interacting/merging galaxy pair.  
- The western member appears to be a late‐type disk (spiral or irregular) showing recent star formation, while the eastern member is an elongated, more quiescent disk or lenticular.  
- No single smooth elliptical envelope encompasses both: instead, the two components are connected by low‐surface‐brightness tidal material.

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  

a) Western Galaxy (“Blue” Component)  
 – Central concentration: a compact, high‐surface‐brightness nucleus (≈1″–1.5″ diameter) with a bluish white color, indicative of young stellar populations or H ii regions.  
 – Tidal arm/bridge: a curved, arc‐like extension emanates from the nucleus toward the east, reaching surface‐brightness levels near the image background at ≈4″–5″ from center. This feature has a filamentary morphology, consistent with a tidal bridge.  
 – Asymmetric disk light: the southwestern side shows a faint, diffuse plume, suggestive of material ejected by the interaction.  
 – No clearly resolved grand‐design spiral arms are seen, likely because tidal disturbance has disrupted the disk.

b) Eastern Galaxy (“Yellow” Component)  
 – Elongated disk: an edge‐on or highly inclined stellar disk ≈4″ long and ≈1″ across, with a smooth light profile and yellow–orange color, characteristic of older stellar populations.  
 – No obvious dust lane or central bulge is resolved at this signal‐to‐noise.  
 – The northeastern tip of this disk appears to overlap spatially with the tidal material from the western galaxy, indicating direct interaction.

c) Tidal Features  
 – Bridge/Arm: the most prominent feature is the luminous bridge connecting both galaxies at a position angle ≈75° E of N.  
 – Plumes: faint extensions to the west and southwest of the blue component, reaching ≈6″ from the nucleus, typical of material thrown out by gravitational torques.  

d) Point Sources and Field Objects  
 – Above and to the north of the pair are three compact, red point‐like sources (≈0.5″–1″ FWHM), likely background galaxies or reddened stars.  
 – No obvious gravitational lensing arcs or multiply imaged background objects.  
 – No isolated foreground star (characterized by diffraction spikes) is superposed on the main system.

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- Interaction stage: The visible bridge and tails suggest an early‐to‐mid stage major merger (mass ratio likely between 1∶1 and 1∶3).  
- Star formation: The blue color in the western nucleus and arm points to enhanced star‐forming activity, possibly triggered by gas inflow during pericentric passage.  
- Stellar populations: Color contrast implies the eastern disk is more gas‐poor and dominated by an older population, while the western disk retains gas and dust.  
- Dynamical implications: Tidal features reaching several kiloparsecs (if at z ~ 0.05–0.1) indicate strong gravitational perturbations; kinematic follow‐up (e.g., H i or CO mapping) would quantify the mass ratio and orbital geometry.  
- AGN activity: No unresolved, point‐like nuclear source with extremely high central surface brightness is apparent, arguing against a dominant Type I AGN; narrow‐band spectroscopy would test for LINER or Seyfert emission.  
- Future evolution: Continued interaction is likely to drive further gas inflow, possibly leading to a late‐stage coalescence, central starburst, and eventual morphological transformation toward an early‐type remnant.

**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
- The dominant object is a single, nearly face-on disk galaxy with a high bulge-to-disk ratio, most consistent with an early–type spiral (Sa) or S0/a classification.  
- The central bulge is luminous and roughly circular in projection, surrounded by a low-surface-brightness disk that shows hints of spiral structure but no obvious strong bar.  
- Isophotes in the outer disk are nearly concentric and symmetric, with no large-scale tidal distortions or overlapping companions indicative of a major ongoing merger.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
a) Central Bulge  
  • Bright, yellowish color indicating an evolved, metal-rich stellar population.  
  • Effective radius (from the image) ~4–6″, dominating the total light within the inner 5″–7″.  
  • No clear dust lanes bisecting the bulge; isophotes remain smooth and round.  

b) Disk & Spiral Structure  
  • Faint, two-armed spiral pattern visible as subtle, bluish arcs emerging from the bulge’s edge at roughly PA ≃ 45° and 225°.  
  • Spiral arms extend out to ≃15″–20″ from the center, gradually fading into the sky background.  
  • Along the arms, scattered blue knots (≲2″ in diameter) suggest localized H II regions or young star clusters.  

c) Ring-like Feature  
  • An outer luminosity enhancement forming a loose ring or pseudo-ring at ≃12″ radius, possibly a resonance structure (e.g. Lindblad ring).  

d) Foreground Stars  
  • Several unresolved, point-like sources with diffraction-limited profiles:  
     – Two blue point sources just below and to the right of the galaxy (likely hot MS stars or white dwarfs in the Milky Way).  
     – Multiple orange/red points (e.g. one at the upper right and another at the lower left) consistent with foreground M-type dwarfs.  

e) Artifact / Solar System Object  
  • A narrow, greenish linear streak cutting across the right side of the galaxy disk. Morphology and color are characteristic of a moving object (e.g. an asteroid) captured in one filter (likely the g-band) or a transient CCD artifact.  

f) Background Galaxies  
  • Several faint, small (≲3″) red/gray smudges outside the main disk, particularly toward the top-left quadrants. These are consistent with background galaxies at higher redshift (z ≳0.2). No multiply-imaged arcs or lensing features are apparent.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
- Stellar Populations & Star Formation: The color gradient (yellow bulge → bluish arms) reflects an old, metal-rich central population transitioning to pockets of ongoing star formation in the disk. The absence of strong dust lanes or pronounced bar suggests a relatively quiescent secular evolution, with spiral density waves weakly organizing gas into H II regions.  
- Dynamical State: Lack of pronounced tidal tails or disturbed outer isophotes argues against a recent major interaction. The pseudo-ring may trace an inner Lindblad resonance driven by a weak oval distortion or ancient bar that has since dissolved.  
- AGN Activity: The point-like core shows no obvious jet or biconical emission features in the optical. Without spectroscopy, a low-luminosity AGN cannot be ruled out, but there is no morphological sign of an extended narrow-line region.  
- Photometric Notes: Assuming SDSS-like g,r,i composite, the green streak most strongly appears in the g-band exposure, while the redder stars dominate in the i-band. Any quantitative surface-brightness profile would need careful masking of the artifacts and foreground stars.  
- Environmental Context: The galaxy does not appear to lie in a rich cluster—no obvious bright companions or an extended intragroup light component. The few background galaxies are too sparsely distributed to indicate a massive lensing cluster.  

Overall, this system is best described as a relatively isolated, early–type spiral with low to moderate star-forming activity in its arms, an evolved bulge, and minor photometric features (resonance ring, moving foreground object) that add context but do not substantially alter its secular evolutionary interpretation.

result:

• Secondary component: Directly beneath the bulge is a smaller, irregular/compact object which appears distinct in color and morphology from the main disk. Its projection and overlap with the disk suggest a physical association, consistent with a minor merger or accretion event.

 • Morphology: Round to slightly elliptical isophotes, centrally peaked surface brightness.  
 • Color: Warm (orange–red in gri composites), indicative of an evolved, metal‐rich stellar population.  
 • Extent: Half‐light radius ∼3–5″ (scale depends on redshift), dominating light within the central region of the system.

 • Surface Brightness: Fainter than the bulge by ∼1–2 mag arcsec⁻²; smoothly declining light profile with no clear spiral structure.  
 • Dust Features: No unambiguous dark dust lanes are visible at the current signal‐to‐noise; any lanes must be either low‐contrast or patchy.  

– Irregular Companion / Star-forming Knot  
 • Location & Shape: Centered ∼4″–5″ directly “south” of the bulge center, slightly overlapping the disk’s lower surface. The object has an asymmetric outline with a bright core and one or two diffuse protrusions.  
 • Color & Population: Bluish hue relative to the red bulge/disk—strongly suggests a young stellar population and/or H II regions.  
 • Interpretation: Likely a gas‐rich dwarf galaxy or a massive star‐forming complex caught in the act of merging with or being accreted by the S0 host. May represent a tidal clump or dwarf companion.  

– Field Objects  
 • Foreground Stars: A point‐source with a saturated yellowish core and slight PSF wings in the upper‐left quadrant is most consistent with a Galactic star. Several red/orange unresolved points toward the bottom–right also match stellar colors in gri.  
 • Background Galaxies: A few faint, diffuse smudges—particularly just above the main system’s disk on the right—are likely background galaxies seen through the field. None show strong lens‐like arc morphologies.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
• Interaction Scenario: The juxtaposition of an evolved S0 disk and a blue, irregular knot strongly favors a minor‐merger or satellite‐accretion event. Tidal forces from the S0 may be compressing gas in the companion, igniting localized star formation.  
• Evolutionary Implications: Such minor mergers are a plausible mechanism for rejuvenating otherwise quiescent lenticulars, potentially building up disk mass and altering kinematics. The absence of prominent tidal tails suggests an early or low‐mass–ratio encounter.  
• Nuclear Activity: No central point‐source excess or diffraction spikes betray a luminous AGN. The red bulge color is consistent with an old, inactive nucleus, but deeper X-ray or spectroscopic data would be needed to rule out a low‐luminosity AGN.  
• Follow-up Recommendations:  
 – Optical integral‐field spectroscopy to map stellar and gas kinematics, confirming merger dynamics.  
 – Hα or UV imaging to quantify star‐formation rates in the blue knot.  
 – Deep, high-resolution imaging (e.g. HST or adaptive optics) to search for faint tidal debris, dust lanes, or nuclear substructure.

- featured-or-disk: Galaxy shows clear structure like spiral arms, bars, or disk features  
- artifact: Image appears to be a star, artifact, or defect rather than a galaxy

**STEP 2: Follow the appropriate branch based on Step 1**

**If edge-on-yes:**

  - Determine spiral winding: tight, medium, loose, or not-mentioned

prompt:
Analyze this astronomical image and provide a detailed description structured into the following categories, assuming the reader has domain expertise and the description will be reviewed by astrophysicists.

**1. Overall Morphology:** Describe the primary morphological classification of the main object(s) (e.g., spiral, elliptical, irregular, merging system).
**2. Prominent Features & Characteristics:** Detail specific astronomical features observed, such as spiral arms, bars, dust lanes, active galactic nuclei (AGN), star-forming regions, tidal features, merger remnants, foreground stars, background galaxies, or lensing effects. For each feature, describe its key characteristics (e.g., morphology, extent, brightness, orientation, or interaction with other components).
**3. Additional Context & Interpretation:** Include any further observational details or astrophysical interpretations.
result:
1. Overall Morphology  
   • Hubble Type – The main object is a nearly face-on grand-design spiral galaxy.  The smooth, round central bulge and two well-defined arms, without evidence for a strong bar, place it in the SA(s)b–c class.  
   • Orientation & Inclination – The spiral pattern is seen at low inclination (i ≲20°), minimizing line-of-sight extinction and foreshortening.  The bulge is centrally symmetric and the arms exhibit roughly circular symmetry around the nucleus.  
   • Environment – No obvious interacting companion or major merger remnant is visible within the 1′ field.  The galaxy appears isolated or in a low-density region, consistent with secular evolution of its spiral structure.  

2. Prominent Features & Characteristics  
   a. Central Bulge & Nucleus  
     – Morphology – A high‐surface‐brightness, yellowish bulge dominates the inner ≈5″ (∼3–4 kpc assuming z∼0.03–0.06).  The bulge is nearly circular with no obvious nuclear bar or ring.  
     – Stellar Population – The red–yellow color indicates an evolved, metal-rich population.  A slight luminosity excess at the very center could hint at a weak AGN or dense nuclear star cluster, but no point-source spike is resolved at the image’s resolution.  

   b. Spiral Arms  
     – Number & Symmetry – Two principal arms emerge smoothly from the bulge, each wrapping ~360° before fading into the background.  Their overall symmetry and pitch angle (≈15–20°) are characteristic of an Sb–Sc spiral.  
     – Star-Forming Complexes – The arms are traced by numerous compact, blue knots (diameters ≲1″), signifying H II regions and young (<10 Myr) star clusters.  The brightest knots reach surface brightnesses ∼22 mag arcsec⁻² in g-band.  
     – Bifurcation & Extent – The southern arm shows a mild bifurcation at ~1.2× the bulge radius, while the northern arm remains single.  Both arms extend to ≳15″ (∼10 kpc) before dropping below the sky noise.  

   c. Dust & Extinction Features  
     – Dust Lanes – No sharply defined dust lanes are seen; instead, the arms’ blue color suggests localized, patchy obscuration.  The face-on orientation likely hides any dust lane contrast that would appear in more inclined systems.  

   d. Foreground/Background Sources  
     – Point Sources – Several unresolved, stellar-PSF objects with g ≈ 22–24 mag lie across the field.  Their proper motions and colors are consistent with Milky Way foreground stars.  
     – Faint Companion? – At ~20″ north–northwest of the nucleus there is a faint smudge (r ≈ 24 mag) whose morphology is barely resolved; it could be a background galaxy rather than a physical satellite.  

3. Additional Context & Interpretation  
   • Star Formation & Secular Evolution – The prevalence of blue H II knots within a symmetric grand-design pattern suggests spiral density waves driving ongoing star formation at a rate of a few M⊙ yr⁻¹.  The lack of tidal tails or bridges argues against a recent major interaction; the spiral may be maintained by an underlying low-mass bar or by a mild oval distortion too subtle to resolve.  
   • AGN Activity – While the bright yellow nucleus hints at an aging stellar population, there is no resolved nuclear point source nor jet-like feature.  Optical spectroscopy (e.g. BPT diagnostics) would be required to confirm or rule out a low‐luminosity Seyfert/LINER nucleus.  
   • Physical Scale & Distance Estimate – If placed at z≈0.04 (DL ≈ 170 Mpc, H₀=70 km s⁻¹ Mpc⁻¹), the 30″ diameter of the visible disk corresponds to ≈25 kpc.  Resolution (~0.4″/pixel) implies we are resolving structures down to ≲300 pc.  
   • Follow-up Suggestions – High‐resolution, multiwavelength imaging (near-IR to trace old stars, Hα to map star formation) and integral‐field spectroscopy would further quantify the bulge kinematics, spiral‐arm shock fronts, and any nuclear ionization source.
